Also called Västgötaspets, believed to share ancestry with the Welsh Corgi. Recognized by Swedish Kennel Club in 1943, AKC in 2007.

breeds.name: Thai Ridgeback
breeds.description: An ancient, medium-sized hound known for the distinctive ridge of hair running along its back, with a muscular, athletic build and an independent, protective nature
breeds.history: An ancient, primitive breed native to eastern Thailand, developed for hunting small game, vermin control, and serving as a guard dog. Its isolation in the region preserved its unique characteristics, including the dorsal ridge, for centuries. One of only three breeds with hair ridge.

breeds.name: Tibetan Mastiff
breeds.description: An ancient and imposing guardian breed with massive size, noble bearing, and dense double coat. Known for its independent nature, impressive presence, and deep, powerful bark.
breeds.history: Ancient guardian breed developed in the isolated Himalayas, used by Tibetan nomads and monasteries to protect livestock, villages, and property. Considered a progenitor of many modern mastiff breeds.

breeds.name: Tibetan Spaniel
breeds.description: Small, compact companion breed with a silky double coat and lion-like mane around the face, known as a 'little lion'. Originally bred by Buddhist monks as monastery watchdogs and companions, featuring an alert expression and confident demeanor.
breeds.history: Ancient breed prized in Tibetan monasteries for over 2,000 years, developed by Buddhist monks to serve as companions and watchdogs on monastery walls. Often given as treasured gifts to royalty and dignitaries.

breeds.name: Tibetan Terrier
breeds.description: Medium-sized, squarely built dog with profuse double coat and snowshoe-like feet, known as the 'Holy Dog of Tibet.' Originally bred as companions, watchdogs, and herders in Tibetan monasteries with expressive eyes and protective long coat.
breeds.history: Ancient breed developed over 2,000 years ago by Buddhist monasteries in Tibet as cherished companions, watchdogs, and herders. Known as 'Holy Dogs' and 'luck bringers,' they were never sold but only given as gifts. Introduced to the Western world in the 1920s.

breeds.name: Toy Fox Terrier
breeds.description: Small, athletic, elegant terrier with short, fine coat and alert, lively demeanor, combining toy breed size with true terrier temperament and the spirit of a larger dog
breeds.history: Developed in the early 20th century in the United States by crossing small Smooth Fox Terriers with toy breeds including Chihuahuas, Manchester Terriers, and Italian Greyhounds to create a smaller, versatile companion and ratter. Recognized by the AKC in 2003.

breeds.name: Treeing Walker Coonhound
breeds.description: Medium to large athletic scent hound with distinctive tricolor coat, bred for tracking and treeing raccoons and other game in rugged terrain. Known for swift endurance, intelligence, and distinctive baying voice.
breeds.history: Developed from English Foxhounds brought to colonial America in 1742, specifically refined by Tennessee breeder Thomas Walker and the Walker family in the 1800s for speed, endurance, and ability to track and tree raccoons in American terrain.

breeds.name: Vizsla
breeds.description: Medium-sized, energetic and graceful gundog of Hungarian origin with a sleek, golden-rust colored coat and athletic build. Known for their affectionate, gentle nature, they are versatile hunters and eager companions with high energy drive.
breeds.history: Ancient Hungarian sporting breed descended from hunting dogs of the Magyar tribes who settled in Hungary over a thousand years ago. Developed as a versatile pointer-retriever by Hungarian nobility, the breed nearly faced extinction after World War II but was preserved and re-established by dedicated enthusiasts.

breeds.name: Weimaraner
breeds.description: Large, sleek, athletic sporting dog with distinctive silver-gray coat and striking amber or blue-gray eyes, known for speed, stamina, and intelligence. Originally bred for hunting large game, earning the nickname 'Gray Ghost' for its coat and stealth.
breeds.history: Developed at the court of Weimar, Germany, in the early 19th century by German nobility who sought to create an all-around hunting dog for large game. The breed's parentage was a closely guarded secret for many years.

breeds.name: Welsh Springer Spaniel
breeds.description: Medium-sized, compact gundog with a distinctive red and white coat and straight, silky feathering. Known for its happy disposition, boundless energy, and versatility in the field as a sporting spaniel built for endurance.
breeds.history: Ancient Welsh breed developed as a versatile gundog to flush and retrieve game birds, mentioned in Welsh laws dating to 300 AD. Officially recognized as distinct from other land spaniels by The Kennel Club in 1902 and AKC in 1906.

breeds.name: West Highland White Terrier
breeds.description: Small, sturdy, and confident terrier from Scotland, characterized by its distinctive dense white double coat, bright inquisitive expression, and lively personality
breeds.history: Developed in the Scottish Highlands to hunt fox, badger, and other vermin. Colonel Edward Donald Malcolm of Poltalloch is credited with developing the modern white breed after one of his reddish terriers was mistaken for a fox and shot, leading him to breed only for white dogs to avoid future hunting accidents

breeds.name: Whippet
breeds.description: Medium-sized, sleek sighthound known for its elegant athletic build with distinctive 'inverted S' shape, explosive bursts of speed, and gentle nature. Originally known as the 'poor man's racehorse'.
breeds.history: Developed in Northern England during the 18th-19th centuries by working-class families, crossing small Greyhounds with fast terriers for rabbit coursing and racing. Recognized by AKC and The Kennel Club.

breeds.name: White Shepherd
breeds.origin: Allemagne/Suisse, developed further in North America
breeds.description: A direct descendant of the German Shepherd Dog, the White Shepherd is a large, athletic working dog with erect ears, striking white double coat, and confident demeanor. Known for its noble expression and versatile capabilities as an intelligent herding breed.
breeds.history: Developed from white-coated German Shepherd Dogs. When white coats were deemed a fault by German breed clubs in the 1930s, fanciers in North America and Europe continued breeding them separately, eventually establishing the White Shepherd as a distinct breed recognized by various registries including UKC and FCI (as Berger Blanc Suisse).

breeds.name: Wire Fox Terrier
breeds.description: Small, compact terrier with distinctive dense wiry coat, beard, and alert expression. This bold, energetic breed was developed for fox hunting and combines confidence with an independent spirit.
breeds.history: Developed in England in the 18th-19th century for fox hunting, working to bolt foxes above and below ground alongside hounds. One of the oldest terrier breeds recognized by major kennel clubs.

breeds.name: Wirehaired Pointing Griffon
breeds.description: Medium-sized versatile gundog with distinctive harsh, wiry coat and characteristic beard and eyebrows. Known as the 'supreme gundog' with excellent pointing and retrieving abilities and an intelligent, friendly disposition.
breeds.history: Developed in the late 19th century by Dutch breeder Eduard Korthals, who worked in both Germany and France. His goal was to create the ultimate versatile walking-hunter's gun dog by crossing various pointing breeds, spaniels, and retrievers. Often called 'Korthals Griffon' in his honor.

breeds.name: Wirehaired Vizsla
breeds.description: Medium-sized Hungarian sporting dog with a distinctive dense, wiry coat and golden rust coloring. Features a robust yet lean build and versatile hunting ability, bred for pointing and retrieving in harsh terrain.
breeds.history: Developed in Hungary in the 1930s by crossing the smooth-coated Vizsla with German Wirehaired Pointers to create a wire-coated hunting dog with weather-resistant coat suitable for harsh terrain and cold water

breeds.name: Xoloitzcuintli
breeds.description: Ancient hairless breed from Mexico available in three sizes (toy, miniature, and standard) and two coat varieties (hairless and coated), known for its loyal, calm, and alert temperament
breeds.history: Ancient breed dating back over 3,000 years with archaeological evidence of existence in Mexico. Highly prized by Aztecs, Maya, and other ancient cultures as companions, healers, guards, and ceremonial dogs. According to myth, believed to guide souls to the afterlife. Nearly extinct but revived in 1950s and recognized by AKC in three sizes.

breeds.name: Yorkshire Terrier
breeds.description: Small toy terrier with long, silky steel blue and golden tan coat and confident, spirited personality. Despite their tiny size, these feisty dogs possess the bold terrier temperament in a compact package.
breeds.history: Developed during the Industrial Revolution in Yorkshire and Lancashire by Scottish weavers and mill workers. Bred to catch rats in textile mills and mines, combining various terrier breeds including the now-extinct Paisley and Clydesdale Terriers.
